history.content:
Can't speak for data 100 or phys 7a, but I'd say 61b is about the same as 61a (maybe less if you're familiar with java) and 16b is a bit more work than 16a.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

At least for me, 61b was a little bit less of a time commitment than 61a, and 16b was quite a bit more than 16a.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The course load personally seems reasonable to me. EE 16B took maybe about the same amount of work as EE 16A for me in the beginning, and it went to about 1.5x the workload towards the end once the final project (the electric car) went underways. CS 61B was about 1.5x the workload of CS 61A throughout the semester (maybe closer to 2x if there was a project due). Physics 7A didn't end up taking me too much time outside lectures and discussions and homeworks (I did physics in high school, but most of my other friends also seemed to have similar work schedules), so if you seriously listen to the lectures and attend discussion sections I wouldn't think you'd need more than a handful of hours dedicated to Physics 7A per week (you might need to attend office hours a few times, though). If I put it into hours, I'd estimate EE 16B to be roughly 5-10 hours outside class/discussion/lab, CS 61B to be closer to 10-15 hours, and Physics 7A to be 2-5 hours, but that was just my experience.

Can't speak for data 100 or phys 7a, but I'd say 61b is about the same as 61a (maybe less if you're familiar with java) and 16b is a bit more work than 16a.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

At least for me, 61b was a little bit less of a time commitment than 61a, and 16b was quite a bit more than 16a.
Can't speak for data 100 or phys 7a, but I'd say 61b is about the same as 61a (maybe less if you're familiar with java) and 16b is a bit more work than 16a.

children.subject: At least when I had Hilfinger for 61B, the projects were nowhere near as long or difficult as his reputation would suggest. Also that semester, 40% of the class got As.
would you guys say that the combination of 61b 16b and 7a would be too much? Hilfinger is also teaching 61b and I've heard the projects take forever :/

I took hilfinger last year when we had gitlet as a project. Class was savage and for me the projects took forever and were very arduous. Projects are the majority of ur grade and if u do around average on all the exams (assuming perfect on projects, hw, labs which isn’t that hard just takes a lot of time) you will get an A/A-.

Agree with above ^

I took 61b, physics 7a, and ds100 together and it was hard but I lived! I'd recommend this schedule with ds100 instead of 16B. 7A won't be too hard if you had a very rigorous AP physics C in high school, otherwise it will be quite challenging, but unlikely you'd get below a B.

I will give my advice with a few caveats. I thought 61b + ee16a was a lot of work. This was a semester in which I was taking 18 units and a very time consuming social sciences class. It was doable but time consuming for me given my lack of previous linear algebra experience. I was taking 61b with Hilfinger which is notoriously difficult. You will find the projects very hard even if you consider yourself a very good programmer because they are designed to really delve into the details of the course.

Then, I took ee16a with Sahai and found his problem sets a bit long and time consuming for the reasons mentioned before. EE 16b is essentially ee16a in steroids and might be doable or not depending on who teaches it (for example, I found a lot of my time this past semester gravitating towards ee16b because I really didn't get a lot from Jaijeet's lectures). That is, if 16b clicks with you, it will be very easy. Otherwise, it will be pretty hard, because it does cover a wide array of things all of which are decently challenging.

Now, what definitely would be hard is dealing with the ee16b car + the last 61b project. When I took 61b with Hilfinger he made us implement a vcs similar to git (a slightly more simplified version) due at the end of dead week. This project is INCREDIBLY time consuming and particularly hard because of lack of starter code. Then, the ee16b car is due in the last week of classes. If you are on track with the car and no difficulties come up you will have enough time to devote to the 61b project. If that is not the case, you might end up putting countless hours into fixing the car. For me, it had small things that were not working but that made it seem as if everything was wrong so we essentially re-did the whole project in the week it was due

I would recommend you to take 61b with ee16b and data 100. There's many variables regarding those classes projects that might compromise your time studying for finals. Also, if ee16b is taught as it was taught this semester in the future, the final will be extremely theorical and you would probably want to have a decent amount of time to focus on it. 61b final when I took it was way easier and more fair than the midterms but very unpredictable, so you basically want to hit all topics with a fair amount of time. Physics 7a (from what I've heard) is also a test you have to study a decent amount for and data 100 seems to be one of the light-iest workload classes of the department do I'd go with that one if I were you

history.content: I am currently signed up for ee 16b, cs 61b, and physics 7a in the fall semester but am wondering if this workload may be too much as I really want to ensure that I have enough time to do my best in these classes. Can anyone comment on the workload of 61b compared to 61a and 16b compared to 16a? I am considering switching out physics for data 100 as this was a course that I was really interested in, but is likely less work than 7a. If anyone has taken data 100, what was the workload like? Any advice greatly appreciated! Thanks!
history.subject: ee 16b + cs61b + phys 7a
